Text: @GorskiPhilip @mboorstein @PaulFroese I wonder why journalists haven't explored the buses of Orthodox Jews who attended the rally, or many Hindu nationalists who also share in Trump fervor. There were photos of an Indian flag in front of the Capitol building.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit antisemitism according to the IHRA definition. It discusses media coverage of diverse groups attending an event and notes the presence of flags without targeting Jews or expressing hateful content. There are no elements like blaming Jews for wrongdoing, denying history, or using stereotypes, so it doesn't qualify as antisemitic.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not explicitly target Jews but instead discusses the presence of various groups at a rally. It notes Orthodox Jews and Hindu nationalists sharing Trump's fervor, along with an Indian flag near the Capitol. This discussion does not involve antisemitic content as defined by the JDA, which requires discrimination against Jews specifically. While linking diverse groups to political events can be controversial or stereotypical, it doesn't meet the threshold of antisemitism as outlined in the guidelines.

Text: shut the fuck up, you racist, pro terrorist pig @kathlyngadd Hamas seeks to exterminate israel and jews , you parasite https://t.co/9bopvRXMYC
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet uses derogatory language and makes inflammatory accusations against a person associated with Hamas, implying support for violence against both Israel and Jews. This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism by targeting Jewish individuals through harmful stereotypes and associations. The mention of "exterminate" and dehumanizing terms like "parasite" further reinforce the antisemitic nature of the tweet.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet uses derogatory language targeting a person assumed to be Jewish, associates Hamas with seeking to exterminate both Israel and Jews, and thus reinforces antisemitic tropes linking Jews to harm. This aligns with the JDA's definition of antisemitism, which includes hostility towards Jews based on their identity, even if tied to broader political causes.

IHRA_Explanation: The tweet exhibits antisemitic elements by discounting Arab agency in the 1948 conflict, implying Jewish suffering as a result of their actions, and comparing self-defense to the Allies in WWII‚Äîa classic antisemitic tactic that oversimplifies history and delegitimizes Palestinian suffering.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet contains elements that align with antisemitic tropes by framing historical events in a manner that essentializes Jewish actions and exaggerates their role in the conflict, potentially reinforcing stereotypes and using charged language that could be interpreted as antisemitic.

Text: @AmerZahr @bellahadid @GiGiHadid you are not pro palestine because you are pro genocide to all jews, stop the excuse palestine dont have freedom when their leaders can easily avail thousand of missiles worth hundred millions of dollars while they cant provide proper school or hospital to its citizens.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet in question contains language that aligns with the IHRA definition of antisemitism. Specifically, it uses the term "genocide to all jews," which falls under the category of harmful stereotypes about Jews conspiring to harm humanity. By conflating support for Palestine with promoting genocide against Jews, the tweet employs a severe and incendiary rhetoric that targets Jewish individuals based on their nationality or beliefs. This aligns with IHRA's examples of antisemitism, where accusing Jews of conspiring in genocidal acts is considered antisemitic. Thus, this tweet meets the criteria for antisemitic expression as it promotes harmful stereotypes and conflates different issues to incite hate against a specific group.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet uses antisemitic language by falsely accusing Jewish individuals of supporting genocide and linking the failure of Palestinian governance to a pro-genocide stance against Jews. This aligns with JDA guidelines on classic antisemitism, which includes stereotypes about Jewish conspiracies and collective responsibility for harm against others. The use of "genocide" and equating criticism of Palestinian leaders with antisemitic behavior directly targets Jewish individuals, fitting the definition of antisemitism as discrimination against Jews because of their identity.

Text: The recent spike in antisemitic attacks against Jews around the country and the world is horrific, heartbreaking & demands action. Antisemitism cannot be tolerated. We must come together as Americans to condemn and combat this appalling bigotry and hatred.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet expresses concern about antisemitic attacks against Jews and condemns such behavior without promoting any stereotypes, conspiracy theories, or negative attributions about Jewish identity. It does not align with the IHRA definition of antisemitism as it doesn't target Jews with hatred or false allegations but instead focuses on combating antisemitic acts themselves.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit antisemitic behavior as it condemns antisemitism by addressing attacks against Jewish individuals. It aligns with opposing hate rather than promoting stereotypes or targeting Jews unjustly.

Text: This is the 2nd week the DSS have detained Rudy Rochman, filmmaker Noam Leibman & French-Israeli Journalist David Benaym. They were shooting a documentary on Nigerian Jews & have visited many locations in Alaigbo. DSS alleged that they were training IPOB/ESN & spying on Nigeria. https://t.co/1AD2ghUUw0
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet contains elements that align with the IHRA definition of antisemitism. It involves an accusation against Jewish individuals (Rochman, Leibman, Benaym) for activities linked to their work on a documentary about Nigerian Jews. The DSS's claim that they were spying or training IPOB/ESN could be seen as an antisemitic stereotype, implying dual loyalty or covert operations, which falls under the IHRA's examples of antisemitism targeting Jewish individuals or groups. Additionally, the detention is based on their perceived Jewish activities, fitting the criminal acts defined by IHRA as antisemitic when targets are selected for being Jewish.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet describes the detention of three Jewish individuals‚ÄîRudy Rochman, Noam Leibman, and David Benaym‚Äîfor alleged espionage while conducting a documentary on Nigerian Jews. According to the JDA definition, antisemitism involves discrimination against Jews as Jews or Jewish institutions. Here, the individuals were targeted because they are Jewish and involved in a project related to Jewish communities. This aligns with antisemitic principles outlined in guidelines 2 (linking Jews to evil) and 3 (targeting Jewish institutions), as well as point 10 (denying rights of Jews to exist as such). The context suggests their Jewish identity was a factor in the detention, making it an example of indirect antisemitism.

Text:
Pro-Palestinian protesters beat an elderly Jewish man in Canada.
It is not about "the Israeli-Palestinian conflict", this is about hating Jews.
Same motive for the conflict in Gaza-Israel.
RT!
https://t.co/dsPqmVQlvH
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet describes an attack on a Jewish man in Canada as motivated by "hating Jews" and links it to the Gaza-Israel conflict. This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, which includes targeting Jews for violence or blaming them collectively for conflicts. The statement directly attributes the act of violence to Jew-hatred, making it an antisemitic expression.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet describes an incident where pro-Palestinian protesters attacked an elderly Jewish man in Canada. It explicitly states that this attack is motivated by antisemitism, not political conflict, and links it to the broader Israeli-Palestinian conflict. According to the JDA, antisemitism involves hostility or violence against Jews as Jews, which includes targeting individuals based on their identity rather than their political views. The use of terms like "hating Jews" and linking the attack to motives involving Jewish people directly aligns with the definition and examples provided in the JDA guidelines, specifically those that involve direct acts of hostility against Jews.

Text: Anti-Semitic Mobs Harassed Orthodox Jews in Brooklyn on Shabbat - https://t.co/C21OpCWJ1v @JewishPress\nhttps://t.co/42ATkRaSU8 https://t.co/uxgCcNp68w
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet describes an incident where a mob identified as anti-Semitic harassed Orthodox Jews in Brooklyn, targeting them based on their Jewish identity. This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, which includes physical manifestations directed at Jewish individuals, regardless of broader conspiratorial accusations. Thus, the tweet meets the criteria for antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet uses the term "Anti-Semitic Mobs" and describes an incident where Orthodox Jews were targeted. According to the JDA, antisemitism involves discrimination or hostility against Jews. Here, the mob's actions are framed as antisemitic, directly linking the harassment to their Jewish identity. This meets the criteria of direct antisemitism, as outlined in the guidelines, making the tweet antisemitic.

Text: Muslim Actress Quotes 'Hitler' in Tweet as Hamas Fires Rockets into Israel: 'I Would Have Killed all of the Jews of the World'   https://t.co/LfnVHMmPFT these are SAME people that lied everyday a/b covid death & infection numbers & are promoting the deadly vaccines
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet contains a quote wishing harm upon Jews, which directly aligns with antisemitic rhetoric. Furthermore, the comparison to lying about COVID statistics and promoting vaccines could imply a broader conspiracy or negative stereotype against Jews, supporting the classification of antisemitism as per IHRA's definition.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet references a statement by a Muslim actress expressing a desire to kill all Jews, which directly promotes hostility against Jewish people. This aligns with the JDA's definition of antisemitism, as it involves prejudice and hostility against Jews as Jews, specifically through violent language that targets them collectively. Additionally, the quote reflects the harmful stereotype of Jews being linked to evil or violence, as outlined in guidelines 2 and 3. Therefore, this content meets the criteria for antisemitism under the JDA framework.

Text:
Only India is doing well during this Cov lockdown. All are jealous. 

Western media bitches about India for they know India will be this planet's No1 Superpower in 11 years.

India must discard "R" Economics. Indians dont want Economic advise from White Jews/their Indian agents. https://t.co/pOdi55CWZr
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet contains elements that align with IHRA's definition of antisemitism. It accuses White Jews of collectively advising India, implying a negative and unwelcome influence. This reflects mendacious allegations about Jewish involvement in economic matters, fitting the criteria for antisemitic behavior as defined by IHRA.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet targets White Jews and their supposed influence over India's economy through agents. It suggests that these individuals are giving bad economic advice, which aligns with classic antisemitic tropes about Jewish control or manipulation. This collective blame of Jewish people for negative economic policies or influence is considered antisemitic as it reflects negatively on Jewish groups without justification and adheres to racist stereotypes. Additionally, the mention of "R" Economics could imply a derogatory term related to Jews, further supporting the antisemitic nature of the statement. The tweet thus violates the JDA guidelines by perpetuating harmful stereotypes and coded language against Jewish people.

Text:
Education is not memorizing that Hitler killed 6 millions Jews. 

Education is understanding how millions of ordinary Germans were convinced that it was required. 

Education is learning how to spot the signs of history repeating itself.
IHRA_Explanation: While the tweet's mention of "history repeating itself" could be interpreted as a sensitive reference, it does not explicitly target Jewish individuals, communities, or Israel. The content focuses on historical education and cautionary advice without involving antisemitic tropes or direct attacks on Jews. Thus, it doesn't fit the IHRA definition of antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not contain any content that can be classified as antisemitic. It discusses historical events, including the Holocaust, in an educational context without targeting Jews or using antisemitic stereotypes. The mention of spotting signs of history repeating itself is a cautionary note about preventing future atrocities and does not involve discrimination against Jews. Therefore, according to the JDA definition, this tweet is not antisemitic.

Text: Google "Siege of Leningrad" and Finnish army.  Even if the fascist army had Jews in it..... It is still bad to commit atrocities. https://t.co/7SQh8s2RzJ
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit antisemitic behavior as defined by IHRA. It discusses historical military actions and condemns atrocities without targeting Jews or implying any conspiratorial or negative stereotype about them. The focus is on the moral condemnation of war crimes, not on blaming Jews as a group for such actions.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not meet the criteria for antisemitism as defined by the JDA. It references historical events and makes a moral judgment about atrocities, acknowledging the possible presence of Jews in the Finnish army during WWII but emphasizing that committing such acts is still condemned. This statement does not involve racialization or negative stereotyping of Jews, nor does it promote conspiracy theories or incite hatred against them. The user's observation is a factual historical reference and a moral judgment about actions, protected under free speech principles. Therefore, the tweet is not considered antisemitic according to the JDA guidelines.

Text: @ConnollyBooks You forgot deported jews and persecuted gays and lesbians
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet is considered antisemitic according to the IHRA definition. It accuses a group (Jews) of being overlooked in historical context, which reflects outdated stereotypes and the perception of Jewish victimhood. This critique implies that Jews collectively should bear the burden of historical acknowledgment, aligning with antisemitic narratives. While not overtly hateful, it reinforces negative stereotypes and the idea that Jews are owed recognition, which can be seen as antisemitic.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet references "deported jews," which targets Jewish individuals based on their identity. While it also mentions persecuted gays and lesbians, the primary focus is on Jews. According to the JDA, this kind of generalized criticism or exclusion of Jews as a group constitutes antisemitism. The mention of "deported jews" implies negative treatment or oversight of Jewish people, aligning with the definition of discrimination against Jews as Jews. Therefore, the tweet is considered antisemitic.

Text: @DowlerMarie The implication, of course, is that the lives of the brutally oppressed, dispossessed & routinely murdered Palestinians are less important than the desires of UK Jews. Appalling racism right there. Of, course many Jews do not feel that & to suggest otherwise is itself antisemitic https://t.co/Rfp247OwtS
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet uses language that dehumanizes and makes derogatory comparisons between Jewish people's needs and the lives of Palestinians. It implies that Palestinian suffering is less important than UK Jews' desires, which aligns with antisemitic tropes that prioritize Jewish interests over others. This can be seen as making mendacious or stereotypical allegations about Jews, thus fitting the IHRA definition of antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet compares the lives of Palestinians to those of UK Jews, suggesting that the latter are more important. This prioritization based on identity constitutes discrimination against Palestinians, aligning with antisemitic criteria that devalue certain groups over others. The comparison reduces Palestinian suffering to a less important status, reflecting a form of discrimination and dehumanization, thereby meeting the JDA's definition of antisemitism.

Text:
üö®ANTISEMITE ALERT üö® 

Lying about Jews & abusing the Holocaust!

Hajj Amin al-Husseini planned extermination of Jews with Himmler & Eichmann when a guest of Hitler 1941-45!

Nazi ideology is containing in Hamas & PLO Charters!

Arafat was a blood relative!

#Antisemitism https://t.co/iu4mqJAipN https://t.co/mZ2oekB1RS
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet uses Holocaust denial and equates Nazi ideology with current groups like Hamas and PLO, targeting Jews. This aligns with IHRA's examples of antisemitism through Holocaust denial and conspiracy theories linking Jews to atrocities.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet is antisemitic according to the JDA definition. It denies the Holocaust by accusing lying about Jews and the Holocaust, thus minimizing its reality (JDA point 5). It links Jews with evil ideologies by associating Hamas and PLO with Nazi beliefs and references Arafat's Jewish roots in a context that could imply conspiracy (JDA points 2 and 4). The use of aggressive language like "alert" and inciting hatred through historical references aligns with antisemitic speech, reinforcing stereotypes and stigmatization.

Text: Mayor @SadiqKhan‚Äôs  Londonistan echoes with ‚Äòdiversity‚Äô as his jihadis parade the streets, calling to ‚Äúf**k  the #Jews and their daughters.‚Äù \nhttps://t.co/6jkirR4M9Z
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet explicitly uses vulgar and hate-filled language targeting Jewish individuals and their daughters, which fits the IHRA definition of antisemitism by manifesting as verbal attacks against a specific religious group.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet contains explicit antisemitic content targeting Jews. It uses vulgar language to demean Jewish individuals and their daughters, directly attacking them based on their ethnicity. This aligns with the JDA definition of antisemitism, which includes hostility against Jews as Jews. The mention of "jihadis" may not be central to the antisemitic aspect but amplifies the context of hostility in London, while the offensive language and gendered attack on Jewish women clearly constitute antisemitism.

Text: They want Jews and Israel for their Rapture. https://t.co/xHPzKW5qvM
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet "They want Jews and Israel for their Rapture" can be interpreted as making a stereotypical or mendacious accusation about Jews, implying they are being used by others. This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, which includes targeting Jewish collectivities like the state of Israel and involves dehumanizing or negative stereotypes about Jews. Therefore, the tweet is considered antisemitic.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet references a stereotype that associates Jewish people with a conspiratorial end-time scenario, known as the Rapture, within Christian theology. This implies that Jews are being manipulated or targeted by others for their own eschatological goals. Such associations link Jews to negative stereotypes and conspiracies, aligning with classical antisemitic tropes outlined in the JDA guidelines. Therefore, this tweet is considered antisemitic as it discriminates against Jews based on their religious identity, utilizing harmful stereotypes.

Text: @medeabenjamin I know that you would sooner give no money to Israel, but remember the Palestinians started the war, they want all of Israel Jew free. Where would that leave all Jews? Back to the Holocaust, with no country of our own, when thrown out of other countries. Now we have our land back
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet employs a classic antisemitic analogy by equating the hypothetical loss of Israel's Jewish identity with the Holocaust, thereby dehumanizing Jews. It links the existence of Israel to preventing another catastrophe, evoking fear and implying a necessity for Jewish enclaves to avoid annihilation. This aligns with IHRA's definition, which identifies such language as antisemitic due to its threatening nature towards the Jewish community.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet invokes antisemitic themes by comparing Jewish expulsion from Israel to the Holocaust, a severe historical atrocity. This comparison demoralizes Jews and aligns with classical antisemitic tropes of persecution and conspiracy. Additionally, it implies that non-Israeli Jews are disloyal, which is another form of harmful stereotyping. The mention of wanting Israel free of Jews also reflects the racist ideology of excluding a Jewish population, further confirming its antisemitic nature.

Text: @violetpetalss Yes, the Nakba was when Arabs would rather abandon their homes than live near Jews. Everyone knows about it.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet references the Nakba and suggests that Arabs would rather abandon their homes than live near Jews. This implies a negative stereotype about Jewish people being unwilling to coexist with others, which aligns with antisemitic tropes. It uses historical events to convey a biased view that could incite hatred or discrimination against Jews.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet references the Nakba with a phrasing that implies Arabs avoid living near Jews, reflecting negative stereotypes about Jews. This aligns with JDA guidelines B.2 and B.6, indicating antisemitism by linking Jews to exclusion or displacement, thereby promoting harmful stereotypes.

Text: @JimMFelton @stephenpollard Not enough dead Jews for Felton.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet in question, "@JimMFelton @stephenpollard Not enough dead Jews for Felton," does not clearly meet the criteria for antisemitism as defined by IHRA. While the phrase "Not enough dead Jews" could be interpreted as dehumanizing or offensive, it lacks the explicit antisemitic elements such as conspiracy theories, Holocaust denial, or collective blame of Jews. Without additional context indicating a targeted attack on Jewish people or community, this appears to be a sarcastic or dismissive remark rather than an overtly antisemitic statement.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet "@JimMFelton @stephenpollard Not enough dead Jews for Felton." references the Holocaust by stating that "Not enough dead Jews" died, which can be interpreted as minimizing or denying the severity of the Holocaust. This aligns with JDA guideline 5, which considers such actions antisemitic. The mention of dead Jews specifically targets Jewish people and downplays historical atrocities, perpetuating antisemitic ideas. Therefore, this tweet is classified as antisemitic.

Text: @JoshoftheWired @KamiW9 @ArtifactsHub Just look at the Jews. His chosen people.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet refers to "Jews" as "His chosen people," which implies a negative stereotype where Jews are unfairly favored or blamed. This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, particularly in its use of stereotypes to negatively critique individuals based on their perceived Jewish identity.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet refers to Jews as "His chosen people," which could imply that all Jews are part of this group without individual choice. This aligns with antisemitic tropes where Jews are seen as a collective with certain attributes, potentially leading to discrimination or hostility against them as individuals because of their Jewish identity.

Text: @marceelias @mehdirhasan My guide in Budapest showed the shoe memorial on Danube where the shoes were kept after Jews were shot in the river. Orban is bringing this back. When I asked her how he got in power she said, ‚Äúrural folk listening to state-run TV‚Äù. https://t.co/hr9mRzYa5f
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet discusses historical atrocities against Jews and references a political figure's rise to power. It mentions rural support for Orban, influenced by state-run media, but does not target Jews or use antisemitic stereotypes. The focus is on political commentary rather than Jewish groups. Thus, it does not meet the criteria for antisemitism as defined by IHRA.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not contain any statements that fit the definition of antisemitism as outlined by the JDA. It references a historical memorial related to the Holocaust, which is a factual event, and mentions political commentary about how a leader gained power through rural support and state media. There's no indication of antisemitic stereotypes, Holocaust denial, or other antisemitic elements. The discussion revolves around historical context and political observations, which are not inherently antisemitic.

Text: What's particularly jarring to me about this photo is that the woman holding the antisemitic sign looks like an enviously chic French stereotype. Just a reminder that it's not just basement-dwellers and white hood-wearers who hate Jews; the hate has gone mainstream. https://t.co/aqjP1NJSTt
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet references an antisemitic sign and describes a woman using a stereotype that could imply negative Jewish characteristics. It notes the mainstreaming of antisemitism beyond specific groups, aligning with IHRA's definition, which includes targeting Jews through stereotypes and rhetoric that demonizes them. Thus, it meets the criteria for antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet associates a person holding an antisemitic sign with a stereotype, implying that antisemitism can manifest across various demographics. It targets Jewish identity by linking the individual's actions to antisemitic beliefs, thus aligning with the JDA's definition of antisemitism as discrimination against Jews as Jews.

Text:
Terr0rist country Pakistan supports Palestine so it's obvious that Swara supports Palestine. 
1. India gave refuge to Jews fleeing Nazi gen0cide 
2. and even today #IndiaStandsWithIsrael 

@ReallySwara needs treatment. https://t.co/qXvnKdep0R
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet uses derogatory language towards Pakistan by calling it a "terrorist country," which targets the country for supporting Palestine, a stance often critical of Israel. It also accuses Swara of supporting Pakistan's position and dismisses her views as incorrect or mentally unstable. These actions align with antisemitic behaviors, such as dehumanizing remarks and making mendacious allegations against Jewish supporters or their allies.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet uses derogatory language towards Pakistan, equating its support for Palestine with terrorism, a classical antisemitic trope. By linking Pakistan's support to terrorism and criticizing it, the author associates this stance with antisemitism, indirectly targeting Jewish individuals through coded language. Additionally, calling someone out for treatment based on their support for Palestine could incite hostility against Jews, aligning with JDA guidelines on indirect antisemitism.

Text: 11 August 1942 | A transport of 559 Jews deported from #Westerbork in the German-occupied Netherlands arrived at #Auschwitz. After the selection 164 men & 131 women were registered. \n\nThe remaining 264 people were killed in a gas chamber, incl. a 2-year old Magdalena Dora Blau. https://t.co/jDJSw7uqxx
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet provides a factual account of historical events during the Holocaust, specifically detailing the arrival of Jews at Auschwitz. It does not contain any antisemitic content, such as hatred towards Jews, stereotyping, or Holocaust denial. Instead, it offers information about a tragic chapter in history, which aligns with the aim of remembrance and education rather than spreading antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet provides factual historical information about the Holocaust, specifically mentioning the arrival of Jews at Auschwitz in 1942. It does not contain any antisemitic content, including stereotypes, generalizations, or implications linking Jews to evil forces. Instead, it accurately recounts a tragic event from history and thus does not violate the JDA definition.

Text: 3/ When the idea of Israel was mooted, plenty of Jewish people were against the idea. \n\nAmong the early opposition of the idea was the Hasidic Jews especially the Neturei Karta group.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet references historical Jewish opposition to Israel and specifically mentions the Neturei Karta group, which is known for opposing Zionism. While criticizing Israel as a country is not inherently antisemitic, this tweet frames the opposition in a way that could perpetuate negative stereotypes about Jewish loyalty or imply a collective disloyalty among Jews, aligning with IHRA's examples of antisemiticism. Therefore, it crosses into territory that reflects antisemitic narratives, making it antisemitic according to the provided definition.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet mentions historical opposition by some Jewish groups, such as Neturei Karta, to the idea of Israel. This is a factual statement about differing Jewish opinions on Zionism and does not attack Jews for their identity or imply that opposing Israel is inherently antisemitic. According to JDA guidelines, this type of historical criticism is protected and not considered antisemitic.

Text:
Isn't it a bit weird that the press NEVER talk to Jews in Corbyn's own constituency, the ones who invite him to their celebrations, and vote for him, why they support him?

Journalism 101, surely
#ItWasAScam
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit antisemitism according to IHRA's definition. It critiques media behavior towards Jewish supporters of Corbyn and suggests press bias without promoting harmful stereotypes or accusing Jews of wrongdoing. While it may imply certain perspectives, it doesn't align with the specific criteria for antisemitism as outlined by IHRA.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet suggests that Jewish voters in Jeremy Corbyn's constituency are unseen or insincere in their support for him. This implies a stereotype that Jewish communities have hidden motives, aligning with classical antisemitic notions of Jewish influence and manipulation. While not explicitly antisemitic, the implication of stereotyping can be seen as coded language under guidelines that prohibit essentializing or negatively generalizing about Jewish populations. The use of "#ItWasAScam" further hints at a negative perception, contributing to an indirect form of antisemitism by suggesting deceptive authenticity in their support. Thus, this tweet adheres to the JDA's criteria for antisemitic speech through stereotyping and coded language.

Text:
This is Yoni Jesner. He was my youth leader growing up in the Glasgow Jewish community. 

In 2002, Yoni was murdered by Hamas in a suicide bomb, he was 19 years old. 

The murder of Jews like Yoni is what is being advocated for when people call for a ‚Äòglobal intifada‚Äô. https://t.co/Q88iUcCrb3
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet connects the murder of Yoni Jesner by Hamas to calls for a "global intifada," which can be interpreted as supporting violence against Jews or Israelis. This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, as it involves blaming Jews for violence and inciting hatred towards Jewish individuals. Therefore, the tweet meets the criteria for antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit antisemitic behavior as defined by the JDA. It expresses sorrow over Yoni Jesner's murder and links it to the "global intifada" concept without promoting discrimination or hostility toward Jews. The focus is on a specific tragedy, not on any group-based hatred or prejudice against Jewish people.

Text: Hitler got off light when he attempted a coup; 10 years later he laid waste to western civilization and killed millions of Slavic People, gypsies, mentally challenged and Jews.  Those who ignore the Lessons of History are condemned to relive them.   #VoteBlueToSaveAmerica https://t.co/5sFSfAHyEa
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet references historical events where Hitler targeted various groups, including Jews. It lists Jews as victims alongside others, which aligns with IHRA's examples of blaming Jews collectively for historical atrocities. This can be seen as a form of antisemitism that targets Jewish individuals by associating them with past crimes, even if the intent isn't to incite hatred but rather to discuss history. By implicating Jews in these events, it reinforces harmful stereotypes and meets the criteria outlined by IHRA for antisemitic behavior.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet references Hitler's atrocities, including the killing of Jews, and uses specific mention of "Jews" alongside other groups. This could reinforce negative stereotypes about Jewish people, aligning with antisemitic tropes that link Jews to historical evil. The reference to ignoring lessons of history and comparing it to repeating such errors can be seen as minimizing or trivializing the Holocaust's gravity, thus violating the JDA's guidelines against antisemitism by targeting Jews specifically.

Text: Los Angeles: Arabs attack Jews at a Sushi restaurant. https://t.co/gHjA5awp8s
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet does not provide sufficient context or evidence to determine that the attack was motivated by antisemitism. While it mentions Arabs attacking Jews, there is no indication that the attack was targeting Jews specifically due to their identity or that the sushi restaurant was Jewish-owned. Without such context, the incident cannot be classified as antisemitic according to the IHRA definition.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet describes an attack on Jewish individuals by Arabs at a sushi restaurant. According to the JDA definition, antisemitism includes hostility against Jews as Jews. This incident directly targets Jews, fitting the criteria of antisemitic behavior as outlined in the guidelines.

Text: US and Germany announce partnership to combat Holocaust denial | By Josh Axelrod https://t.co/rQSZxeRsAS
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet announces a partnership between the US and Germany aimed at combating Holocaust denial. It does not contain any content that singles out Jews, promotes negative stereotypes, or accuses Jewish individuals or collectives of wrongdoing. Instead, it focuses on an initiative to address a historical issue, which aligns with efforts to combat antisemitism rather than promote it. Therefore, the tweet is not antisemitic according to the IHRA definition.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet announces a partnership between the US and Germany to combat Holocaust denial. This is a collaborative and constructive effort aimed at addressing an important issue. The JDA guidelines specify that it is not antisemitic to criticize or oppose policies or states in a way that is evidence-based (guideline 13). The content of the tweet does not involve any negative stereotypes, classical antisemitic tropes, or coded language directed at Jews. Instead, it highlights a positive initiative to address Holocaust denial, which aligns with the principles of combating misinformation and promoting awareness. Therefore, the tweet does not meet the criteria for antisemitism as defined by the JDA.

Text: @BowenBBC Get tae feck you absolute racist guttersnipe sending this out to Jews on Shabbat morning. The fuck do you think you are? Impartial at @BBCNews @bbc @BBCPolitics are we? Now do it to Islam, I dare you, you snivelling racist wretch.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet uses racial slurs targeting Jewish individuals during a specific time (Shabbat), which is a clear manifestation of antisemitic rhetoric. It also implies a double standard by challenging the same treatment for Islam, reinforcing stereotypes about Jews being unfairly targeted. This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, as it involves verbal attacks and biased accusations directed at Jewish individuals collectively.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet uses derogatory language targeting a Jewish individual and refers to Shabbat, a significant Jewish day. It also compares this treatment to that of Islam, potentially implying a double standard or coded antisemitic remarks. The language employed is offensive and directly hostile towards Jews, aligning with the JDA's definition of antisemitism as discrimination against Jews.

Text: Morons insulting Jews horrifically murdered by the Nazis. https://t.co/mdUlgbhrM7

By invoking the Holocaust to belittle Jewish people, the tweet targets Jews with hostility, thereby violating the JDA guidelines. Therefore, this tweet is considered antisemitic.

Text: "Videos are piling up from LA, New York, London and Germany showing Jews being surrounded and beaten in the streets in scenes reminiscent of the run-up to the Holocaust, the Farhuds and so many other similar bloodlettings," writes @EdwinBlackBook. https://t.co/tADtU3h3wT

The use of historical analogies, combined with descriptions of physical attacks on Jewish people, underscores a pattern of discrimination against Jews based on their identity. Therefore, this tweet meets the criteria for antisemitic speech.

Text: Palestinian refugee from 1948 agrees with the Israeli narrative exactly: We were told us to leave our homes for two weeks while they destroy the Jews. We thought that was a long time. That was 50 years ago.\nWatch and SHARE with your favorite #Israel hater! https://t.co/iicxmJlAB7

Text: Dalia Lamkus, 25-year old woman was murdered by Palestinian terrorist for no reason other than being Jewish.\nShe was murdered in cold blood as a direct result of the Palestinian Authority's terror policy of paying salaries to terrorists for killing Jews. https://t.co/74thMyKjyO
